mn32:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gosiṅgasālavanadāye viharati sambahulehi abhiññātehi abhiññātehi therehi sāvakehi saddhiṃ—
mn32:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the sal forest park at Gosiṅga, together with several well-known senior disciples, such as
mn32:1.2.comm: From MN 31:3.1 we know that this park was near Ñātika in the Vajjian country.

mn32:1.3.pli: āyasmatā ca sāriputtena āyasmatā ca mahāmoggallānena āyasmatā ca mahākassapena āyasmatā ca anuruddhena āyasmatā ca revatena āyasmatā ca ānandena, aññehi ca abhiññātehi abhiññātehi therehi sāvakehi saddhiṃ.
mn32:1.3.eng: the venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākassapa, Anuruddha, Revata, Ānanda, and others.

mn32:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā mahākassapo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ etadavoca:
mn32:2.1.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa, and said,

mn32:2.2.eng: “Come, Reverend Kassapa, let’s go to Venerable Sāriputta to hear the teaching.”

mn32:2.3.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā mahākassapo āyasmato mahāmoggallānassa paccassosi.

mn32:2.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca mahāmoggallāno āyasmā ca mahākassapo āyasmā ca anuruddho yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu dhammassavanāya.
mn32:2.4.eng: Then, together with Venerable Anuruddha, they went to Sāriputta to hear the teaching.

mn32:3.1.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantañca mahāmoggallānaṃ āyasmantañca mahākassapaṃ āyasmantañca anuruddhaṃ yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamante dhammassavanāya.

mn32:3.2.pli: Disvāna yenāyasmā revato tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ revataṃ etadavoca:
mn32:3.2.eng: went to Venerable Revata, told him what was happening,

mn32:3.3.pli: “upasaṅkamantā kho amū, āvuso revata, sappurisā yenāyasmā sāriputto tena dhammassavanāya.

mn32:3.4.pli: Āyāmāvuso revata, yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamissāma dhammassavanāyā”ti.

mn32:3.5.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā revato āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.

mn32:3.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ca revato āyasmā ca ānando yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu dhammassavanāya.

mn32:4.1.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantañca revataṃ āyasmantañca ānandaṃ dūratova āgacchante.
mn32:4.1.eng: Sāriputta saw them coming off in the distance

mn32:4.4.pli: Svāgataṃ āyasmato ānandassa bhagavato upaṭṭhākassa bhagavato santikāvacarassa.
mn32:4.4.eng: Welcome to Ānanda, the Buddha’s attendant, who is so close to the Buddha.

mn32:4.5.pli: Ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso ānanda, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā, maññe, gandhā sampavanti;
mn32:4.5.eng: Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and heavenly scents seem to float on the air.

mn32:4.6.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso ānanda, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā”ti?
mn32:4.6.eng: What kind of mendicant would grace this park?”

mn32:4.7.pli: “Idhāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu bahussuto hoti sutadharo sutasannicayo. Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthā sabyañjanā; kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti, dhātā, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.
mn32:4.7.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and penetrating them theoretically.
mn32:4.7.comm: Ānanda was renowned as the most learned monk in the Sangha (AN 1.219).

mn32:4.8.pli: So catassannaṃ parisānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti parimaṇḍalehi padabyañjanehi anuppabandhehi anusayasamugghātāya.
mn32:4.8.eng: And they teach the four assemblies in order to uproot the underlying tendencies with well-rounded and coherent words and phrases.
mn32:4.8.comm: Typically inclusive, Ānanda mentions the four assemblies of monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.

mn32:4.9.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā”ti.
mn32:4.9.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.”

mn32:5.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ revataṃ etadavoca:
mn32:5.1.eng: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Revata,

mn32:5.2.pli: “byākataṃ kho, āvuso revata, āyasmatā ānandena yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
mn32:5.2.eng: “Reverend Revata, Ānanda has answered by speaking from his heart.

mn32:5.3.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ revataṃ pucchāma:
mn32:5.3.eng: And now we ask you the same question.”

mn32:5.4.pli: ‘ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso revata, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā, maññe, gandhā sampavanti;

mn32:5.5.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso revata, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti?

mn32:5.6.pli: “Idhāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu paṭisallānārāmo hoti paṭisallānarato, ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyutto anirākatajjhāno, vipassanāya samannāgato, brūhetā suññāgārānaṃ.
mn32:5.6.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who enjoys retreat and loves retreat. They’re committed to inner serenity of the heart, they don’t neglect absorption, they’re endowed with discernment, and they frequent empty huts.
mn32:5.6.comm: There were two prominent Revatas in the early Sangha. There was Revata of the Acacia Wood, who was said to be the foremost of forest dwellers (AN 1.203, Thag 14.1, Thag 1.42). But this is probably Revata the Doubter, who was the most skilled in jhāna (AN 1.204, Thag 1.3). Early in his monastic life he struggled with doubt over small maters (Kd 6:16.1.1). He overcame this (Ud 5.7), but the name stuck.

mn32:5.7.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā”ti.
mn32:5.7.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.”

mn32:6.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn32:6.1.eng: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Anuruddha,

mn32:6.2.pli: “byākataṃ kho, āvuso anuruddha, āyasmatā revatena yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
mn32:6.2.eng: “Reverend Anuruddha, Revata has answered by speaking from his heart.

mn32:6.3.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ pucchāma:
mn32:6.3.eng: And now we ask you the same question.”

mn32:6.4.pli: ‘ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso anuruddha, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā, maññe, gandhā sampavanti;

mn32:6.5.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso anuruddha, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti?

mn32:6.6.pli: “Idhāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena sahassaṃ lokānaṃ voloketi.
mn32:6.6.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who surveys a thousandfold galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human,
mn32:6.6.comm: Anuruddha is identified as foremost in clairvoyance at AN 1.192. | The verb voloketi (“surveys”) is an elevated usage, only used of Anuruddha’s ability (see AN 3.130:2.2) and when describing a Buddha “surveying” the world (MN 26:21.1).

mn32:6.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso sāriputta, cakkhumā puriso uparipāsādavaragato sahassaṃ nemimaṇḍalānaṃ volokeyya;
mn32:6.7.eng: just as a person with clear eyes could survey a thousand orbits from the upper floor of a royal longhouse.
mn32:6.7.comm: This power is compared (in the Majjhima) with a man standing between two doors watching people come to and fro (MN 39:20.3, MN 77:35.2, MN 130:2.1), and (in the Dīgha) with someone in a longhouse watching people move about in the town square (DN 2:96.1, DN 10:2.33.1). The unique phrasing here evokes the Wheel that manifests to a Wheel-Turning Monarch as he stands upstairs in the royal longhouse, which is thousand-spoked and complete with rim (sahassāraṁ sanemikaṁ, MN 129:34.2, DN 26:4.9). The simile was evidently unclear to the ancients, as one Chinese parallel has instead “a thousand bricks” (presumably laid out to dry in the sun, MA 184 at T i 727b14). In the Pali tradition, nemimaṇḍala is the outer cladding of a wheel rim, often iron (see commentary to Ja 475). However, normally sutta similes draw directly from experience, and it is hard to imagine how one would survey a thousand wheel rims (unless perhaps a king overseeing chariot construction in his forecourt?) On the other hand, the Wheel is a solar symbol and nemimaṇḍala could easily refer to the orbits of the stars, which would explain “looking at the sky” of EA 37.3 ( at T ii 711a3). On balance, I think the simile refers to a star-gazing king.

mn32:6.8.pli: evameva kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena sahassaṃ lokānaṃ voloketi.

mn32:6.9.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā”ti.
mn32:6.9.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.”

mn32:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ etadavoca:
mn32:7.1.eng: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Mahākassapa,

mn32:7.2.pli: “byākataṃ kho, āvuso kassapa, āyasmatā anuruddhena yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
mn32:7.2.eng: “Reverend Kassapa, Anuruddha has answered by speaking from his heart.

mn32:7.3.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ pucchāma:
mn32:7.3.eng: And now we ask you the same question.”

mn32:7.4.pli: ‘ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso kassapa, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā, maññe, gandhā sampavanti;

mn32:7.5.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso kassapa, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti?

mn32:7.6.pli: “Idhāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu attanā ca āraññiko hoti āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca piṇḍapātiko hoti piṇḍapātikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca paṃsukūliko hoti paṃsukūlikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca tecīvariko hoti tecīvarikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca appiccho hoti appicchatāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca santuṭṭho hoti santuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca pavivitto hoti pavivekassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca asaṃsaṭṭho hoti asaṃsaggassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca āraddhavīriyo hoti vīriyārambhassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca sīlasampanno hoti sīlasampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca samādhisampanno hoti samādhisampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca paññāsampanno hoti paññāsampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca vimuttisampanno hoti vimuttisampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca vimuttiñāṇadassanasampanno hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanasampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī.
mn32:7.6.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who lives in the wilderness, eats only almsfood, wears rag robes, and owns just three robes; and they praise these things. They are of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praise these things. They are accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom; and they praise these things.
mn32:7.6.comm: Mahākassapa’s austere lifestyle was renowned (AN 1.191).

mn32:7.7.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā”ti.
mn32:7.7.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.”

mn32:8.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavoca:
mn32:8.1.eng: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Mahāmoggallāna,

mn32:8.2.pli: “byākataṃ kho, āvuso moggallāna, āyasmatā mahākassapena yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
mn32:8.2.eng: “Reverend Moggallāna, Mahākassapa has answered by speaking from his heart.

mn32:8.3.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ pucchāma:
mn32:8.3.eng: And now we ask you the same question.”

mn32:8.4.pli: ‘ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso moggallāna, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā, maññe, gandhā sampavanti;

mn32:8.5.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso moggallāna, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti?

mn32:8.6.pli: “Idhāvuso sāriputta, dve bhikkhū abhidhammakathaṃ kathenti, te aññamaññaṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti, aññamaññassa pañhaṃ puṭṭhā vissajjenti, no ca saṃsādenti, dhammī ca nesaṃ kathā pavattinī hoti.
mn32:8.6.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s when two mendicants engage in discussion about the teaching. They question each other and answer each other’s questions without faltering, and their discussion on the teaching flows on.
mn32:8.6.comm: In the suttas, abhidhamma means “about the teaching”. Here the prefix abhi- conveys the same sense as the English “meta-”. | This is a surprising topic for Moggallāna, and all three Chinese parallels as well as Sanskrit fragments say Moggallāna praised psychic powers, in which he was the recognized expert (AN 1.190). It seems certain the Pali is corrupt here, and MA 185 more plausibly attributes discussion on the teaching to Mahākaccāna.

mn32:8.7.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā”ti.
mn32:8.7.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.”

mn32:9.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahāmoggallāno āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:

mn32:9.2.pli: “byākataṃ kho, āvuso sāriputta, amhehi sabbeheva yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
mn32:9.2.eng: “Each of us has spoken from our heart.

mn32:9.3.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ pucchāma:

mn32:9.4.pli: ‘ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā, maññe, gandhā sampavanti;
mn32:9.4.eng: Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and heavenly scents seem to float on the air.

mn32:9.5.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti?
mn32:9.5.eng: What kind of mendicant would grace this park?”

mn32:9.6.pli: “Idhāvuso moggallāna, bhikkhu cittaṃ vasaṃ vatteti, no ca bhikkhu cittassa vasena vattati.
mn32:9.6.eng: “Reverend Moggallāna, it’s when a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it.
mn32:9.6.comm: While one might expect Sāriputta to praise wisdom, all the parallels agree on this point. Indeed, Sāriputta also speaks in a similar way on mental mastery at SN 46.4.

mn32:9.7.pli: So yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharati;
mn32:9.7.eng: In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.

mn32:9.8.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharati;

mn32:9.9.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati sāyanhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā sāyanhasamayaṃ viharati.
mn32:9.9.eng: and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.

mn32:9.10.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso moggallāna, rañño vā rājamahāmattassa vā nānārattānaṃ dussānaṃ dussakaraṇḍako pūro assa.
mn32:9.10.eng: Suppose that a ruler or their chief minister had a chest full of garments of different colors.

mn32:9.11.pli: So yaññadeva dussayugaṃ ākaṅkheyya pubbaṇhasamayaṃ pārupituṃ, taṃ tadeva dussayugaṃ pubbaṇhasamayaṃ pārupeyya;
mn32:9.11.eng: In the morning, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.

mn32:9.12.pli: yaññadeva dussayugaṃ ākaṅkheyya majjhanhikasamayaṃ pārupituṃ, taṃ tadeva dussayugaṃ majjhanhikasamayaṃ pārupeyya;

mn32:9.13.pli: yaññadeva dussayugaṃ ākaṅkheyya sāyanhasamayaṃ pārupituṃ, taṃ tadeva dussayugaṃ sāyanhasamayaṃ pārupeyya.
mn32:9.13.eng: and in the evening, they’d don whatever pair of garments they wanted.

mn32:9.14.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso moggallāna, bhikkhu cittaṃ vasaṃ vatteti, no ca bhikkhu cittassa vasena vattati.
mn32:9.14.eng: In the same way, a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it.

mn32:9.15.pli: So yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharati;
mn32:9.15.eng: In the morning, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.

mn32:9.16.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharati;

mn32:9.17.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati sāyanhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā sāyanhasamayaṃ viharati.
mn32:9.17.eng: and in the evening, they abide in whatever meditation or attainment they want.

mn32:9.18.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso moggallāna, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā”ti.
mn32:9.18.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.”

mn32:10.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto te āyasmante etadavoca:
mn32:10.1.eng: Then Sāriputta said to those venerables,

mn32:10.2.pli: “byākataṃ kho, āvuso, amhehi sabbeheva yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
mn32:10.2.eng: “Each of us has spoken from the heart.

mn32:10.3.pli: Āyāmāvuso, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṃ bhagavato ārocessāma.
mn32:10.3.eng: Come, reverends, let’s go to the Buddha, and inform him about this.

mn32:10.4.pli: Yathā no bhagavā byākarissati tathā naṃ dhāressāmā”ti.
mn32:10.4.eng: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”

mn32:10.5.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te āyasmanto āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

mn32:10.6.pli: Atha kho te āyasmanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn32:10.6.eng: Then those venerables went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. Venerable Sāriputta told the Buddha of how the mendicants had come to see him, and how he had asked Ānanda:

mn32:11.1.pli: “idha, bhante, āyasmā ca revato āyasmā ca ānando yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu dhammassavanāya.

mn32:11.2.pli: Addasaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhante, āyasmantañca revataṃ āyasmantañca ānandaṃ dūratova āgacchante.

mn32:11.5.pli: Svāgataṃ āyasmato ānandassa bhagavato upaṭṭhākassa bhagavato santikāvacarassa.

mn32:11.6.pli: Ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso ānanda, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā, maññe, gandhā sampavanti;
mn32:11.6.eng: “‘Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and heavenly scents seem to float on the air.

mn32:11.7.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso ānanda, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’ti?
mn32:11.7.eng: What kind of mendicant would grace this park?’

mn32:11.8.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, āyasmā ānando maṃ etadavoca:
mn32:11.8.eng: When I had spoken, Ānanda said to me:

mn32:11.9.eng: ‘Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who is very learned …

mn32:11.11.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti.
mn32:11.11.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.’”

mn32:11.13.pli: Yathā taṃ ānandova sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
mn32:11.13.eng: Ānanda answered in the right way for him.

mn32:11.14.pli: Ānando hi, sāriputta, bahussuto sutadharo sutasannicayo. Ye te dhammā ādikalyāṇā majjhekalyāṇā pariyosānakalyāṇā sātthā sabyañjanā; kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ abhivadanti, tathārūpāssa dhammā bahussutā honti, dhātā, vacasā paricitā, manasānupekkhitā, diṭṭhiyā suppaṭividdhā.

mn32:11.15.pli: So catassannaṃ parisānaṃ dhammaṃ deseti parimaṇḍalehi padabyañjanehi anuppabandhehi anusayasamugghātāyā”ti.

mn32:12.1.pli: “Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, āyasmantaṃ revataṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn32:12.1.eng: “Next I asked Revata the same question.

mn32:12.2.pli: ‘byākataṃ kho, āvuso revata, āyasmatā ānandena yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.

mn32:12.3.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ revataṃ pucchāma—

mn32:12.4.pli: ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso revata, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā maññe gandhā sampavanti.

mn32:12.5.pli: Kathaṃrūpena, āvuso revata, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’ti?

mn32:12.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, āyasmā revato maṃ etadavoca:

mn32:12.7.pli: ‘idhāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu paṭisallānārāmo hoti paṭisallānarato, ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyutto, anirākatajjhāno, vipassanāya samannāgato, brūhetā suññāgārānaṃ.

mn32:12.8.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti.
mn32:12.8.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.’”

mn32:12.10.pli: Yathā taṃ revatova sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
mn32:12.10.eng: Revata answered in the right way for him.

mn32:12.11.pli: Revato hi, sāriputta, paṭisallānārāmo paṭisallānarato, ajjhattaṃ cetosamathamanuyutto anirākatajjhāno, vipassanāya samannāgato brūhetā suññāgārānan”ti.

mn32:13.1.pli: “Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn32:13.1.eng: “Next I asked Anuruddha the same question.

mn32:13.3.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso anuruddha, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’ti.

mn32:13.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho maṃ etadavoca:

mn32:13.5.pli: ‘idhāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena sahassaṃ lokānaṃ voloketi.
mn32:13.5.eng: ‘It’s a mendicant who surveys the thousandfold galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human …

mn32:13.7.pli: evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti.
mn32:13.7.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.’”

mn32:13.8.pli: “Sādhu sādhu, sāriputta, yathā taṃ anuruddhova sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
mn32:13.8.eng: “Good, good, Sāriputta! Anuruddha answered in the right way for him.

mn32:13.9.pli: Anuruddho hi, sāriputta, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena sahassaṃ lokānaṃ voloketī”ti.
mn32:13.9.eng: For Anuruddha surveys the thousandfold galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human.”

mn32:14.1.pli: “Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn32:14.1.eng: “Next I asked Mahākassapa the same question.

mn32:14.2.pli: ‘byākataṃ kho, āvuso kassapa, āyasmatā anuruddhena yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.

mn32:14.3.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ mahākassapaṃ pucchāma …pe…

mn32:14.4.pli: kathaṃrūpena kho, āvuso kassapa, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’ti?

mn32:14.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, āyasmā mahākassapo maṃ etadavoca:

mn32:14.6.pli: ‘idhāvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu attanā ca āraññiko hoti āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca piṇḍapātiko hoti …pe… attanā ca paṃsukūliko hoti …pe… attanā ca tecīvariko hoti …pe… attanā ca appiccho hoti …pe… attanā ca santuṭṭho hoti …pe… attanā ca pavivitto hoti …pe… attanā ca asaṃsaṭṭho hoti …pe… attanā ca āraddhavīriyo hoti …pe… attanā ca sīlasampanno hoti …pe… attanā ca samādhisampanno hoti …pe… attanā ca paññāsampanno hoti … attanā ca vimuttisampanno hoti … attanā ca vimuttiñāṇadassanasampanno hoti vimuttiñāṇadassanasampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī.
mn32:14.6.eng: ‘It’s a mendicant who lives in the wilderness … and is accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom; and they praise these things.

mn32:14.7.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti.
mn32:14.7.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.’”

mn32:14.9.pli: Yathā taṃ kassapova sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
mn32:14.9.eng: Kassapa answered in the right way for him.

mn32:14.10.pli: Kassapo hi, sāriputta, attanā ca āraññiko āraññikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca piṇḍapātiko piṇḍapātikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca paṃsukūliko paṃsukūlikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca tecīvariko tecīvarikattassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca appiccho appicchatāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca santuṭṭho santuṭṭhiyā ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca pavivitto pavivekassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca asaṃsaṭṭho asaṃsaggassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca āraddhavīriyo vīriyārambhassa ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca sīlasampanno sīlasampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca samādhisampanno samādhisampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca paññāsampanno paññāsampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca vimuttisampanno vimuttisampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī, attanā ca vimuttiñāṇadassanasampanno vimuttiñāṇadassanasampadāya ca vaṇṇavādī”ti.
mn32:14.10.eng: For Kassapa lives in the wilderness … and is accomplished in the knowledge and vision of freedom; and he praises these things.”

mn32:15.1.pli: “Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ bhante āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn32:15.1.eng: “Next I asked Mahāmoggallāna the same question.

mn32:15.2.pli: ‘byākataṃ kho, āvuso moggallāna, āyasmatā mahākassapena yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.

mn32:15.3.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ mahāmoggallānaṃ pucchāma …pe…

mn32:15.4.pli: kathaṃrūpena, āvuso moggallāna, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’ti?

mn32:15.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, āyasmā mahāmoggallāno maṃ etadavoca:

mn32:15.6.pli: ‘idhāvuso sāriputta, dve bhikkhū abhidhammakathaṃ kathenti. Te aññamaññaṃ pañhaṃ pucchanti, aññamaññassa pañhaṃ puṭṭhā vissajjenti, no ca saṃsādenti, dhammī ca nesaṃ kathā pavattinī hoti.
mn32:15.6.eng: ‘It’s when two mendicants engage in discussion about the teaching …

mn32:15.7.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti.
mn32:15.7.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.’”

mn32:15.8.pli: “Sādhu sādhu, sāriputta, yathā taṃ moggallānova sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
mn32:15.8.eng: “Good, good, Sāriputta! Moggallāna answered in the right way for him.

mn32:15.9.eng: For Moggallāna is a Dhamma speaker.”

mn32:16.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā mahāmoggallāno bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn32:16.1.eng: When he had spoken, Moggallāna said to the Buddha,

mn32:16.3.pli: ‘byākataṃ kho, āvuso sāriputta, amhehi sabbeheva yathāsakaṃ paṭibhānaṃ.
mn32:16.3.eng: ‘Each of us has spoken from our heart.

mn32:16.4.pli: Tattha dāni mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ pucchāma—

mn32:16.5.pli: ramaṇīyaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, gosiṅgasālavanaṃ, dosinā ratti, sabbaphāliphullā sālā, dibbā, maññe, gandhā sampavanti.
mn32:16.5.eng: Sāriputta, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and heavenly scents seem to float on the air.

mn32:16.6.pli: Kathaṃrūpena, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’ti?
mn32:16.6.eng: What kind of mendicant would grace this park?’

mn32:16.7.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, āyasmā sāriputto maṃ etadavoca:
mn32:16.7.eng: When I had spoken, Sāriputta said to me:

mn32:16.8.pli: ‘idhāvuso moggallāna, bhikkhu cittaṃ vasaṃ vatteti no ca bhikkhu cittassa vasena vattati.
mn32:16.8.eng: ‘Reverend Moggallāna, it’s when a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it …

mn32:16.9.pli: So yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharati;

mn32:16.10.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharati;

mn32:16.11.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati sāyanhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā sāyanhasamayaṃ viharati.

mn32:16.12.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso moggallāna, rañño vā rājamahāmattassa vā nānārattānaṃ dussānaṃ dussakaraṇḍako pūro assa.

mn32:16.13.pli: So yaññadeva dussayugaṃ ākaṅkheyya pubbaṇhasamayaṃ pārupituṃ, taṃ tadeva dussayugaṃ pubbaṇhasamayaṃ pārupeyya;

mn32:16.14.pli: yaññadeva dussayugaṃ ākaṅkheyya majjhanhikasamayaṃ pārupituṃ, taṃ tadeva dussayugaṃ majjhanhikasamayaṃ pārupeyya;

mn32:16.15.pli: yaññadeva dussayugaṃ ākaṅkheyya sāyanhasamayaṃ pārupituṃ, taṃ tadeva dussayugaṃ sāyanhasamayaṃ pārupeyya.

mn32:16.16.pli: Evameva kho, āvuso moggallāna, bhikkhu cittaṃ vasaṃ vatteti, no ca bhikkhu cittassa vasena vattati.

mn32:16.17.pli: So yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharati;

mn32:16.18.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharati;

mn32:16.19.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati sāyanhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā sāyanhasamayaṃ viharati.

mn32:16.20.pli: Evarūpena kho, āvuso moggallāna, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā’”ti.
mn32:16.20.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.’”

mn32:16.22.pli: Yathā taṃ sāriputtova sammā byākaramāno byākareyya.
mn32:16.22.eng: Sāriputta answered in the right way for him.

mn32:16.23.pli: Sāriputto hi, moggallāna, cittaṃ vasaṃ vatteti no ca sāriputto cittassa vasena vattati.
mn32:16.23.eng: For Sāriputta masters his mind and is not mastered by it …”

mn32:16.24.pli: So yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ viharati;

mn32:16.25.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā majjhanhikasamayaṃ viharati;

mn32:16.26.pli: yāya vihārasamāpattiyā ākaṅkhati sāyanhasamayaṃ viharituṃ, tāya vihārasamāpattiyā sāyanhasamayaṃ viharatī”ti.

mn32:17.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn32:17.1.eng: When he had spoken, Sāriputta asked the Buddha,

mn32:17.3.eng: “You’ve all spoken well in your own way.
mn32:17.3.comm: The Buddha gives positive reinforcement, not only to the wholesome qualities of others, but to the fact that they appreciate their own good qualities. This is not conceit, but a form of rejoicing (muditā).

mn32:17.4.pli: Api ca mamapi suṇātha yathārūpena bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyya.
mn32:17.4.eng: However, listen to me also as to what kind of mendicant would grace this sal forest park at Gosiṅga.

mn32:17.5.pli: Idha, sāriputta, bhikkhu pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā ujuṃ kāyaṃ paṇidhāya parimukhaṃ satiṃ upaṭṭhapetvā:
mn32:17.5.eng: It’s a mendicant who, after the meal, returns from almsround, sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence, thinking:
mn32:17.5.comm: While the others spoke of results, the Buddha speaks of causes. Compare MN 123:22.1, where the Buddha similarly brings the conversation back to meditation practice.

mn32:17.6.pli: ‘na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ pallaṅkaṃ bhindissāmi yāva me nānupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccissatī’ti.
mn32:17.6.eng: ‘I will not break this sitting posture until my mind is freed from the defilements by not grasping!’

mn32:17.7.pli: Evarūpena kho, sāriputta, bhikkhunā gosiṅgasālavanaṃ sobheyyā”ti.
mn32:17.7.eng: That’s the kind of mendicant who would grace this park.”

mn32:17.8.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn32:17.9.pli: Attamanā te āyasmanto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
mn32:17.9.eng: Satisfied, those venerables approved what the Buddha said.
